title: Question 90

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of bilateral breast pain that begins before her menstrual period and resolves after the onset of menstruation. She reports no other breast symptoms, masses, or nipple discharge. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her grandmother at age 67 years. Her only medication is a combined hormonal oral contraceptive pill.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Bilateral breast examination results are normal, with no masses or nipple discharge. There is no lymphadenopathy.
A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

If a clinical breast examination is normal, management of bilateral cyclic breast pain is conservative and includes education, reassurance regarding the absence of malignancy, wearing a supportive and well-fitting bra, and topical NSAID therapy.
Danazol is the only FDA-approved agent for cyclic breast pain but should be considered only in women with severe pain in whom conservative management has failed.

). This patient has bilateral cyclic breast pain. Most common in women aged 20 to 39 years, cyclic breast pain is often diffuse and bilateral, occurs during the premenstrual phase, and resolves with onset of menstruation; it is usually associated with hormonal changes and is typically benign. If findings on clinical breast examination (CBE) are normal, additional screening for malignancy beyond age-appropriate screening is not required. Cyclic breast pain should be managed conservatively with education, reassurance regarding the absence of malignancy, and wearing a supportive and well-fitting bra. Although some patients benefit from topical NSAID therapy, pain resolves spontaneously for most women. There is a lack of evidence to support limiting caffeine intake or using vitamin E as a means of mitigating the pain.

Given this patient's age, she does not qualify for routine screening mammography, and her family history does not suggest a hereditary cancer syndrome that would qualify for early screening. Mammography would be the most appropriate management in patients older than 30 years who present with noncyclic focal breast pain or have an abnormal CBE. Noncyclic breast pain is often caused by medication use (contraceptive agents, hormone replacement therapy, psychiatric medications), underlying breast disease (fibrocystic disease, infection, trauma, cancer), or stretching of the Cooper ligaments (connective tissue that maintains breast structural integrity).
